description.text:
Recently I had to unscrew many BNC connectors to be able to replace some of them.
I have some socket wrenches in my toolbox but unfortunately not the required dimension for this connector type.
Since the hardware store was already closed and I would have to wait until Monday, I decided to design a matching socket wrench myself and this thing is a result of this decision.
Using this thing I was able to unscrew all BNC connectors.
The walls of the socket are not very thick since I wanted to be able to unscrew connectors mounted very close to each other (->picture).

description.text:
A 250-size quadcopter designed for learning to fly line of sight acro and perform tricks like flips and rolls. Specific design & build features include:

  • Robust 5mm top and bottom plates, with extra reinforcement on the base.
  • Arms also designed to be more robust by adding extra thickness underneath.
  • Side supports add strength and stiffness to the frame.
  • Replacing an arm requires the removal of only 3 bolts for ease and speed.
  • Electronics can be installed such that no re-soldering is required when replacing frame parts

I'd suggest using bright colors for the arms and printing two arms in each color, preferably the color of your props for ease of orientation.

While this quad isn't crash proof, I've crashed it more times without breaking the frame than most of the other 250-size quads I've 3d printed. And when I have crashed and broken something it's always been an arm, which is fairly quick and easy to replace without dismantling the whole quad.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm Layer, 0.4mm Nozzle

Notes:

Printed in PLA.

If you choose to print the anti vibration mounts for the motors, you should print this in a flexible filament like Fileflex or NinjaFlex.

• Betaflight F3 (or better) flight controller. Eg SPRacing F3
  • 20A BLHeli ESC's
  • 2204 2300KV motors
  • 5030 tri-blade props (the tri blades are more visible when flying, which helps with orientation)
  • Turnigy Nanotech 850mAh 3S 45~90C Lipo

This hardware results in a nice smooth quad, with sufficient power for learning tricks and a decent flight time.

Note that I was trying this quad with 4S (hence 4S batteries in the photos) but I had a problem where it would loose control after rapid maneuvers and I couldn't track down why. Eventually I discovered that switching to 3S seems to have "solved" the problem and it flies just fine on 3S.

Also I initially started out with 2-blade 5030 props which were ok, but I find the tri-blade props fly smoother (and they are easier to see)

print_settings.Notes:: I printed mine face down and just supported the reliefs; since they will be covered by the LED strips anyway that seemed to work best.

description.text:
I had some extra 12V LED strips lying around and thought I would try to make my own 7 Segment out of it. I haven't used this in a circuit yet; need to get out the shift registers and transistors. But I have tested with my bench supply and it seems to work OK.

I suggest printing out of a higher temp plastic or soldering the connections before sticking them down. I made a mess out of the back of the print with my soldering Iron -- because I printed in PLA.

I had planned to use RGB strip, but after thinking about wiring for that I decided to do a less challenging version. This should work fine with standard 5050 12V LED strip (each segment is one segment of that).

You may want to consider running these LEDS at 9v instead of 12, they are very bright at 12V.

https://www.instagram.com/p/BXd6xSoAbDG/

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.3MM

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Print with ABS/PETG or some other high temp plastic or figure out how to solder before adhering to the board. Make sure you fold over enough of the strip to do the soldering on the back (the strip doesn't need to go to the end of the gutter on the front -- it's far more important to give yourself room to solder -- but unfortunately there is just so much you can fold over because you can't / don't want to put any leds on the back.).

I printed mine face down and just supported the reliefs; since they will be covered by the LED strips anyway that seemed to work best.

author: daozenciaoyen

description.text:
My second attempt at building a dual-copter, this time with a 3d printed frame and using an X-Racer F3 flight controller running betaflight. Initial hover tests look promising and it flies much better than my previous attempt using a KK2 flight controller.

As well as the parts here, you'll also need

  • two of these: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:519176
  • some 15mm aluminium bar - mine is U shaped so I can hide wires and ESCs underneath.

Current Setup
  • XRacer F303 flight controller with Betaflight 3.1.6
  • 2205 2150KV motors
  • 5045 props
  • Savox SH-0257 digital metal gear servos
  • 3A 5V UBEC
  • 4S 1500 mAh Lipo (or 3s 850mAh also works)

It hovers okay with this setup, but feels a little under-powered, requiring about 60% throttle. I suspect that larger props, or higher KV motors would help, but I was mainly using parts I already had available.

Basic Setup

It took me some time to work out how to set this up in betaflight, so this is roughly what I did:

  • Setup most things how you would for a quad, RX, arm switch, rates, expo, etc.
  • On the configuration tab choose Bicopter.
  • Connect the left motor to M1, right motor to M2
  • Connect left servo to M5, right servo to M6 (probably you can use M3 and M4 if you want)
Set servo PWM rate

The servos were initially a bit jittery, but running servo_pwm_rate set to 300 in the cli smoothed this out.

Map servos
  • Read: https://github.com/betaflight/betaflight/wiki/Servos-&-SERVO_TILT-for-3.1
  • Go to the betaflight cli
  • Use the resource command and make note of what resources motors 3 and above are using.
  • Use the resource motor 3 none command to unmap motor 3. Do the same for 4, 5, 6, 7, 8
  • Map your servos to some resources that you have just freed up from the motors. I did, eg, resource servo 1 B08 and resource servo 2 B09 to map servos 1 and 2 to the same output pins that motors 5 and 6 were using.
Testing
  • Push your pitch stick forward (right stick for mode 2) should tilt both servos forward
  • Pull the pitch stick back should tilt both servos backwards.
  • Yaw left should tilt the right servo forward and the left servo back
  • Yaw right should tilt the right servo backwards and the left servo forwards.

If not, you'll need to do some servo reversing....

Reverse servos

I found that when I pushed the pitch stick forwards, the right servo (S2) tiled forward, but the left servo (S1) tilted back. I figure if I want the copter to pitch forward them both servos should tilt forwards. Reading https://github.com/martinbudden/betaflight/blob/master/docs/Mixer.md I eventually worked out that the command smix reverse listed the current reversed or not reversed servo settings. An 'r' in the table means it is reversed, and 'n' means it is not.

The command smix reverse 4 1 r fixed my problem by reversing (r) the bicopter left servo (4) when mixing in stabilized pitch (1) input.

Betaflight > 3.1.7

Later versions of betaflight removed the BI (copter) mixer on some flight control boards to save space. Fortunately you can replicate the missing mixes by using a custom mix and copying the mix that would have been in the firmware from the betaflight code on github.

After much fiddling around I found that you need a customairplane (this enables both motors and servos)

Mixer: CUSTOMAIRPLANE

Setting up the motor mix was easy enough, these commands worked for me:

mmix reset
mmix 0  1.000  1.000  0.000  0.000
mmix 1  1.000 -1.000  0.000  0.000

Setting up the servos was more troublesome, it took some time for me to get the servos to move at all. I eventually made it work by guessing the servo numbers (2 & 3). This is what worked for me:

smix reset
# smix num servo input ...
smix 0 2 2 100 0 0 100 0
smix 1 2 1 -100 0 0 100 0
smix 2 3 2 100 0 0 100 0
smix 3 3 1 100 0 0 100 0

title: E3D v6 Micro Cooling Fan Duct (4020/5015 Radial Fan)

description.text:
Small and unobtrusive fan duct for the E3D-v6 hotend, for use with either a 4020 or 5015 radial fan.

I like the fangs, but I find them a bit too big and in the way, so I designed this one that has a similar dual exhaust profile to the 'Radial Fan Fang' by Lion4H.

I have experimented with a few different fans (single/dual 3030, 4040, etc) and exhaust profiles and found this configuration to give the best results.

There are 2 stl's available, for left-handed and right-handed versions, however as of writing this I have only experimented with the right-handed version.

No supports needed, just orient it so the front face is on the build plate (stl's should already be oriented the correct way)

Thanks for looking, hope people find this useful!

author: Ferdinand_von_Gummibaum

description.text:
This thing is a simple jig to allow you to grind a groove on a plain roller bearing using an abrasive wheel and a Dremel or other die grinder type equipment. One the reasons you might want to do this is for your extruder idler bearing, this will help keep the filament on axis. One of the problem I have experienced with my (poorly made?) hobbed bolt extruders is the filament wandering up and down the hobbed portion of the bolt. So I was inspired by ebay seller you2bay http://myworld.ebay.co.uk/you2bay/ who sells grooved bearings to have a try at this and it works great. My first attempt was just to grind the bearing by hand but I think this is a much more repeatable method.

Please take care and use safety glasses as a bare minimum safety equipment when ever you are grinding anything.

Setup..
The openSCAD file is dumbly parametric (I.e you need to adjust all the parameters) and I heartily recommend that you spend a little time tuning it before printing out a jig. The 2 stls I have uploaded are based on the dremel slitting disk I had to hand. The most important dimensions are the diameter of the wheel (this will shrink) and the diameter and length of the boss beneath the wheel. Also the clearance of the grinding wheel is important, too little and you are going to melt you guideway. Print 100% infill but be aware that this is a limited use item unless you mahine one from steel. To use..
1) Bolt the bearing in place on the jig using a suitably sized bolt and a washer each side of the bearing. Make sure it spins freely.
2) Wipe any oil of the outside of the bearing
3) Adjust the abrasive wheel so you can slide the wheel down the slot freely, using the back of the fixing boss as a guide on the jig
4) Grind the bearing in a pecking motion, don't let the bearing spin too fast
5) Take you time and dont overheat the bearing

comments.text: I just tried this with PLA for fun (against my better judgement) and it's a one use item. Anyway, due to the melted guideway, I could play with the angle a little more.

description.text:
So you're all ready for this years big Total Solar Eclipse. But you're wondering -- once I put a solar filter on the front of my camera, how do I safely point it at the Sun?

Ponder no more, friend. Just print one of these little gems (preferably in a light color), and you can easily get pointed close enough to the Sun that it'll show up in your camera's screen. Just slide the finder into your camera's hot shoe; when the little post casts no shadow, you're on target.

Note: always be careful when doing solar photography. Unfiltered (or insufficiently filtered) sunlight magnified by your camera's optical path can blind you and / or your camera.

title: Furry EL Wire Lightup Neon Badge

description.text:
Show your furry pride in the day and night with this light-up EL wire furry sign. Designed for 2.2mm EL wire, this (optionally) wearable sign and backing only requires glue and approximately 4' of EL wire for assembly. As you can see by the assembled picture, 3' of wire is slightly too short.

Simply print the "el_wire_template_furry_all_unjoined_final.stl" and "el_wire_template_furry_nameplate_final.stl" files. Assemble with printing material friendly adhesive of choice (i.e. e6000 is cheap and works well for ABS and PLA). Then thread your wire through the holes. Depending on type of print material used you may want to add adhesive to keep wire locked down within the frame if the fit isn't snug enough.

Optional "el_wire_template_furry_nameplate_with_hooks_final.stl" file is included if you would like to wear the sign as a badge.

6' of EL wire with an 2xAA battery powered inverter can be purchased on Amazon for around $5 to $8. e6000 is available online and at most super stores, including Walmart, in the crafting isle for $3.

title: Protective mounting case for iMacwear W1 (a.k.a. DM98)

description.text:
Rugged case to allow mounting iMacwear's W1 wearable Android watch to be mounted on mobile robot

Original design: Lennart Rolland.
For project: OctoMY™ (http://octomy.org).
Description: This is a protective case to make the iMacwear W1 wearable android device, a.k.a. DM98 (link to unboxing of this device here)usable on a mobile robot. The case serves the flowing purposes:

  • Ruggedizes the device to protected from whatever mechanical dangers are lurking in the world of mobile robots.
  • Makes maintaining a permanent retention of the magnetic USB charging/data cable more convenient.
  • Makes attaching the device to RC servo or many other convenient mounting options possible (just add your own geometry to match whatever mounting requirements you may have).

Please note: This is a prototype design that may already have been superseded.

Pros

  • Really tight fit
  • Super light
  • Perfect fit with servo horn
  • Almost snap-on attachment
  • Even looks kind of cool!
  • Retains the cable surprisingly well
  • Very modular and parametereized design that can easily be adapted in all kinds of ways

Cons

  • A bit more fragile than I had hoped. Risk of cracking along layer lines when snapping it in

Overal: Albeit the obvious room for improvement I am still quite happy with the result!

Standard disclaimer: This work is provided as a convenience and for informational purposes only. The original author assumes no responsibility for any adverse effects that may arrise from this work.

Copyright / license: I hereby place this work into the public domain, though if you want to show appreciation and you have robot parts to spare, please consider donating them to the OctoMY™ project http://www.octomy.org/contribute/donation ).

Printer:

Creality CR10

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

$fn=120

Infill:

100% (model is only a shell)

Notes:

Due to the fine details of the case, I would recommend that you use as low layer height and slow print speed as time allows for in your project.

Preparing the W1 for insertion

The W1 has wrist bands extruding from the main body, and they contain the WiFi and GSM antennas for the android device.

If you want to remove the wrist bands, you have to be very careful. I recommend taking of the back lid first and unscrewing the wrist supports (aluminium and plastic parts that keep each strap mounted well). There are two fasteners holding down the support for each strap.

I ended up just tearing of the strips with pliers which in turn broke the antennas. The antennas can be disconnected by two tiny snap on coaxial connectors, and I am hoping to find replacement antennas.

After removing the straps there are still two protrusions on each side of the case. The design is made with those in mind.

This is the backside of the watch showing (faintly) the metal bezels holding the straps On the leftmost strap the mount is clearly visible I have marked WiFi & GSM antenna snap-on connectors and approxiamte location of screws for strap mounts. The watch running an old version of OctoMY™ agent. Pretty awesome! Getting the case on for the first time...

So, you know the first time there is going to be some anxiety. But don't worry, we have you covered. Instead of lube try a little exposure to light hair-dryer.

Be careful not to go too far, it will go all jelly on you!

Made with OpenSCAD

This was made from the ground up in OpenSCAD to be very modular and adaptible.

I have commented each module in the hope that someone else might make sense of it all.

I have included the entire file here for searchability:


$fn=120;
tolerance=0.2;

function hex_dia(dia) = dia * ( 2 / sqrt (3) );

function normalize(v) = v/(sqrt(v[0]*v[0] + v[1]*v[1]));

// General purpose 2D voronoi function used to make structural enhancement
module voronoi(points, L=200, thickness=0.2, rounding=6){
    for (p=points){
        difference(){
            minkowski(){
            intersection_for(p1=points){
                if (p!=p1){
                    translate((p+p1)/2 - normalize(p1-p) * (thickness+rounding)){
                    angle=90+atan2(p[1]-p1[1], p[0]-p1[0]);
                        rotate([0,0,angle])
                        translate([-L,-L])
                        square([2*L, L]);
                    }
                }
            }
            circle(r=rounding);
            }

        }
    }
}

// Utility function to make a rounded rectangular prism using minowski
module rounded_prism(length=1, width=1, height=1, rounding=0.1){
        linear_extrude(height=height){
            minkowski(){
                resize([length-rounding,width-rounding])square(center=true);
                circle(r=rounding/2);
            }
        }
}

// Utility function to make a rounded box using minowski
module rounded_box(length=1, width=1, height=1, rounding=0.1){
    minkowski(){
        resize([length-rounding,width-rounding,height])cube(center=true);
        sphere(r=rounding/2);
    }
}

// The straps and strap mounts of the W1
module strap(length=33, width=20, height=10){
    color("green")difference(){
        rotate([0,0,0])cube([34,20,12], center=true);
        translate([0,13,0])cube([35,21,60], center=true);
        // If you remove the straps so that only strap mounts of the housing remains, you must comment out the following line
        translate([0,0,0])cube([35-10,21,60], center=true);
    }
}

// The gold contactors for the cable and cable mount (only for comparison, not useful in the print)
module contactors(){
    num=4;
    space=9/3;
    diameter=1.5;
    height=1;
    center=(space*(num-1))/2;
    for(i=[0:space:space*(num-1)]){
        color("Goldenrod")translate([0,i-center,0.2])cylinder(diameter=diameter, height=height);
    }
}

// Voronoi based decoration (and mechanical strengthening) for the case
module voronoi_decoration(length= 60,width=60, height=30, resolution=10, thickness=0.2, rounding=0.3, randomness=0.6){
    xs=length/resolution;
    ys=width/resolution;
    rand=rands(0,1,(xs+1)*(ys+1)*2*resolution, seed_value=1337);
    //echo(rand);
    point_set = [
    for (y = [0:resolution:width])
        for (x = [0:resolution:length])
            [ x+rand[x*xs+y]*randomness*resolution, y+rand[x*ys+y]*randomness*resolution ]
    ];
        //echo(point_set);
        translate([-length/2,-width/2, -height/2])linear_extrude(convexity=10, h=height*2)voronoi(points=point_set, L=max(width, length)*2, thickness=thickness, rounding=rounding);
}

// Cutout for only the toothed wheel of RC servo horn
module servo_horn_cutout( tooth_count = 25, tooth_height = 0.3, tooth_length = 0.7, tooth_width = 0.1, head_diameter = 5.92, head_height = 4, head_thickness=0.7, head_screw_diameter=2, screw_area_height=2, screw_area_diameter=4, clearance=0.02) {
    union(){
         cylinder(r = head_diameter / 2 - tooth_height + 0.03 +clearance, h = head_height, $fn=tooth_count*2);
         for (i = [0 : tooth_count]) {
              rotate([0, 0, i * (360 / tooth_count)]) {
                    translate([0, head_diameter / 2 - tooth_height +clearance, 0]) {
                        linear_extrude(height = head_height) {
                            polygon([[-tooth_length / 2, 0], [-tooth_width / 2, tooth_height], [tooth_width / 2, tooth_height], [tooth_length / 2,0]]);
                        }
                    }
              }
         }

    }
}

// Cutout for the attachment point for RC servo including toothed wheel, screw hole and access
module servo_horn_attachment_cutout(tooth_count = 25, tooth_height = 0.3, tooth_length = 0.7, tooth_width = 0.1, head_diameter = 5.92, head_height = 4, head_thickness=0.7, head_screw_diameter=2, screw_area_height=2, screw_area_diameter=4, clearance=0.02){
    servo_horn_cutout( tooth_count, tooth_height, tooth_length, tooth_width, head_diameter, head_height, head_thickness, head_screw_diameter, screw_area_height, screw_area_diameter, clearance );
    translate([0,0,head_height+screw_area_height])cylinder(r1 = screw_area_diameter / 2 + head_thickness ,r2 = (screw_area_diameter / 2 + head_thickness)*1.1, h = head_height );
        translate([0,0,head_height])cylinder(r = head_screw_diameter / 2, h = screw_area_height);
}

// Cutout for the cable
module cable_cutout(length=22, width=6, height=6, rounding=5){
    color("red")union(){
        rounded_prism(width+tolerance,length+tolerance,height+tolerance, rounding);
        translate([0,0,2])rotate([0,90,0])rounded_prism(3.5+tolerance,7+tolerance,40+tolerance, 3);
    }
    translate([0,0,6-0.5])contactors();
}

// Main cutout for the shell
module main_cutout(length=60, width=43.5, height=14.5, rounding=12){
    strap_height=10;
    strap_height_offset=-1;
    power_port_indent_h=1;
    power_port_offset=11;
    port_h=10;
    port_l=20;
    port_r=6;
    bezel_h=2;
    bezel_d=2;
    union(){
        difference(){
            color("blue")translate([0,0,height+rounding/2-tolerance])rounded_box(length=length, width=width, height=height*2, rounding=rounding);
            color("cyan")translate([0,0,height*2-bezel_h])cube([length+1, width+1, height*2], center=true);
            //color("yellow")translate([length/2+port_l/2-power_port_offset,0,-port_h+power_port_indent_h ])rounded_prism(port_l,22,port_h, port_r);
        }
        color("LightSkyBlue")translate([0,0,height-bezel_h])rounded_prism(length-bezel_d, width-bezel_d, bezel_h, (rounding*(length-bezel_d))/length );
        strap_ofs=length/2-7.1;
        translate([0,0,-strap_height/2 + height - strap_height_offset]){
            translate([0,-strap_ofs,0])strap(33,20,strap_height);
            translate([0,strap_ofs,0])rotate([0,0,180])strap(33,20,strap_height);
        }
        translate([length/2-7.5,0,0])contactors();

        translate([length/2-7.5,0,-5])cable_cutout();
    }
}

// The complete object
module complete_w1_holder(){
    length=60;
    width=44;
    thickness=3;
    h=4;
    difference(){
        union(){
            translate([0,0,h/2+6])rounded_box(length=length+thickness, width=width+thickness, height=h, rounding=15);
            translate([length/2-7.5,0,2.5])rounded_box(length=8+thickness, width=24+thickness, height=6, rounding=8);
            difference(){
                grid_t=thickness*0.2;
                color("red")translate([0,0,h/2+6-grid_t])rounded_box(length=length+thickness+grid_t, width=width+thickness+grid_t, height=h, rounding=15);
                color("white")voronoi_decoration(length*0.8,width*0.8, h*2,6,grid_t,0.2,0.2);
            }
            color("gray")translate([0,-19,7])rotate([90,0,0])cylinder(d1=14, d2=9,h=10);
        }
        color("yellow")translate([0,-width/2-8,7])scale([1,-1,1])rotate([90,0,0])servo_horn_attachment_cutout();
        color("indigo")translate([length/2,0,15])rounded_box(length=300, width=9+thickness, height=12+thickness, rounding=2);
        color("magenta")translate([length/2,-13,9])rounded_box(length=thickness, width=thickness, height=thickness, rounding=2);
        translate([0,0,10/2+14])cube([80,60,10], center=true);
        main_cutout(length=length, width=width);
    }

}

rotate([-90,0,0])intersection(){
    //servo_horn_cutout();
    //main_cutout();
    complete_w1_holder();
    //contactors();
    //translate([length/2-7.5,0,-5])cable_cutout();
    //Cable holder
    //  color("pink")translate([25,0,-12])cube([20,30,30], center=true);
}

description.text:
This is an interesting puzzle. I deliberately did not take a picture of it solved. It is more difficult than it seems. There are hundreds of ways to put the pieces together, but it will be EXTREMELY obvious when you get it right. Do not look for anything subtle. Please do not post pictures of it solved, keep the challenge open for others.

I wrote the openscad file, but this is copied from a puzzle that I found in my drawer from years ago. There was no author mentioned on the original. If it helps at all, the letters on the original puzzle were APEGGA, but that organization renamed itself to APEGA, which isn't enough letters for this puzzle anymore.

You can put what ever text you want on the pieces, including words instead of letters.
It is a customizer, so you can change the size of it as well. There is a "gap" you can configure in case the pieces do not fit together very well. It is great if the pieces just fit together, but they are not too loose.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

25

Notes:

You have to have enough infill so that the letters are supported, but otherwise the infill is not that important.

comments.text: While this is a pretty neat puzzle, I just printed it and it required a lot of filing on the tabs. I feel like a bit of tolerance on the size of the tabs would go a long way to making this a better experience.
comments.author: Athakaspen

comments.text:
Thanks for the feedback. I thought of this and included the parameter called "gap". If you find that the spacing between the taps is too tight then make the number bigger.
0.4mm works well for my printer, but maybe you want to try 0.8?
If it is too loose then it won't stick together, and might not be too good.
If you are just testing fit, then set the parameter "WhatToPrint" to 7 and it will just print 2 pieces that you can check how they fit together. The print won't take as long, and you can experiment with different settings.
If you have any other questions I am willing to try and answer them.
comments.author: Athakaspen

comments.text: Oh, alright, I hadn't looked at that. I used the pre-made stl file, so I'm not sure what the tolerances were set to for that model but it was too tight for the pieces to fit together at all in my case. However, I printed it on a cheap Anet A8 kit, so a better machine would likely give more accurate sizes.
comments.author: TheFisherOne

comments.text: Hey no problem. Thanks for printing my design. I think that is one of the weaknesses of 3d printing. It is very hard to print one thing that is supposed to fit inside another. The variations in printers and printer settings is too big. The slicer program probably has a lot to do with it as well. I use Simplify3d, but I can not find a way to export all of the settings in text mode. That way others can get an idea of what they need to adjust.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

description.text:
My workbench is in the basement, and when I record videos of various projects from there, I use my GoPro camera. Rather than working around a tripod that always seems to be in the way, I use this mount that attaches to the floor joists overhead -- now the camera is no longer an obstacle.

Note that this does not screw into the joists -- the two bolts are there only to create enough pressure for the mount to have a tight grip on the joist above.

This print requires a few extra things, some of which you might just have laying around:

  • A 0.5-inch rod of whatever length is appropriate for reaching from the floor joists to where you'd like your GoPro to be. I used aluminum, but, really, anything is fine.
  • Four M6 nuts. These are captive in the design, see the printing instructions below for brief suggestions about how to configure your print to automatically pause at the right moments for you to insert each nut.
  • Four 20mm+ M6 bolts.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Printing this is going to be somewhat more complex than a normal print -- it is composed of three separate parts including four captive M6 nuts. You will need to edit the G-Code your slicer generates to add instructions appropriate for pausing your print at the end of the layer right before the nut area is covered. You will also want to make sure that support material is not printed in the area that the nut will reside -- this is easy to accomplish using Simplify3D, but I'm not sure if that is possible using Cura.

The specific code I use for doing this is as follows; note that you will have to alter this if you are printing on a different machine or via a different process; I've noted below the few more-obvious places that changes might be necessary:

M104 S0              ; Turn bed heater off
M140 S0              ; Turn extruder heater off
G91                  ; Put in relative mode
G1 Z10               ; Raise the extruder by 10mm
G90                  ; Put back in absolute mode
G1 X0 Y0             ; Zero the X & Y
M0 Click To Restart  ; Pause and wait for the user; this instruction works for OctoPrint, but you may need to use a different instruction (perhaps M25 if you are printing from an SD card) depending upon what instructions are available for your printer.
G1 X0 Y0             ; Zero the X & Y (again)
G91                  ; Put in relative mode
G1 Z-10              ; Lower the extruder by 10mm
G90                  ; Put back in absolute mode
M140 S75             ; Heat the bed to 75 degrees (adjust this)
M190 S75             ; Wait until the bed temperature has stabilized around 75 degrees (adjust this)
M104 S240 T0         ; Heat the extruder to 240 degrees (adjust this)
M109 S240 T0         ; Wait until the extruder temperature has stabilized at 240 (adjust this)

title: lens frames for Solar Filters for Nikon and Mirror Lens

description.text:
With the up coming solar eclipse I wanted to photograph it. I didn't want to spend a lot of money on solar filters and really had a hard time finding them.

I bough this cheap lens

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01FEA3SN6/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

the brand ended up being an Opteka, but my reasearch only one company actually makes them so they are all the same.

and

2x of

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00DS7IFQS/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1

My Idea is just to tape the flat film to the frame. I am still waiting on the solar filter film. I will add a photo once it arrives.

there are 2 frames One for a 52 Nokia and a slip fit one for the mirror lens.

description.text:
Modified the symmetrical Festool FS track stop block from Enrico74 for use on Triton TTS1400 tracks.

There's an anti-flip ledge on the Triton tracks that the Festool lacks. This modified STL accounts for that ledge and also shortens the riding depth. Nut and knobs are from the original design and can be downloaded from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:921136.

Printer:

MP Select Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Doesn't Matter

.22mm

25%

Notes:

PLA is fine. Didn't use nuclear green. Orange is best. ;)

Brought the original into Meshmixer and plane cut down to size. Recombine and export. Several tries until I could get a nice test-hold.

Let me know if it needs tweaking - I ran out of the M6 bolt & nuts and just used a printed one for size fitting.

Printable logo for the Away3D realtime 3D engine

Things with this kind of shape can be hard to print as the three pillars may be knocked down by your print head. This can happen as the plastic often warps a little bit, so if you have this problem, just use the alternate file that has supports included. These will hold the pillars in place while printing, but they can be cut off quite easily. This file is also a good test for calibrating your printer for things such as oozing and stringing. The Rhino file is also included, without any booleans applied in case you want to tweak it. ( Away3D is a 3D engine for the Flash Player that uses Stage3D for playback. Read more here http://away3d.com )

title: J-Hook GoPro Adapter for Topeak Handlebar Bag Mount

description.text:
I own a Topeak Handlebar Bag that attaches to my bike via a sturdy plastic mount on my bike's handlebars. Since I really only use that bag when bike touring, why not use the clip as a mount for my Gopro when I'm commuting to and from work?

This is a slight modification of my earlier design of a similar mount allowing me to have to carry around only the camera housing and the J-Hook adapter when removed from my bike. This specific design also carries the added benefit that it's quite a lot less sensitive to weak plastics.

title: Hypercube Evolution XY carriage (NO Brass inserts needed and less rod play version)

description.text:
NO brass inserts needed on this. It uses standard M3 nuts.

Its been a while since i made these but I think they both versions use 8mm X axis rods but the difference is one one version uses 8mm Y rods and the other uses 10mm Y rods.
If you need a version that uses 10mm X axis rods I saw someone had remixed it on here some place.

If you like this you might like the no brass inserts bearing holder also: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2436180

8.5.17 8mm X, 8mm Y...Remix of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2437440/#comment-1465527
Modifying the XY carriage to add stability to the 8mm x axis rods. I do not like how much play there is at the hot end with the stock carriage.
If this does not fix the issue I will change to 10mm hollow bearing rods (not the carbon or aluminum crap people are using.)

Also made a generic belt tensioner for my belt that connects the two z steppers

8.7.17 uploaded the simplify3d .factory file with supports for the XY carriage that i created with simplify 3d for use on my 300x300mm creality cr-10 printer

I printed two of the carriages and they appear to look good as far as i can tell so far. I need to print the clamps and the flag before i can mount them.
Also, the carriages use m3x35mm screws with lock nuts but you could get away with m3x30mm regular nuts if thats all you have available.

*** the 3030 optical sensor board holder here I did not create. Just tossing up for people to modify if if does not align with the flag.
My machine does not have the standard 100mm carriage frame spacing so I will be making a custom optical board sensor holder.

8.8.17 Added Y flag with some cutouts to clear the screw nearby. Not tested but should be pretty close to fix if it doesnt totally fit by shaving a little off the bottom.

The slots for the nuts on the XY carriage are tighter than i want for the screws that hold the clamp on in rev 4.

Rev. 4,1 Added 10mm XY carriage and clamp. Need to print test the 10mm version.

8.12.17 Added some stuff for a Z axis flag sensor holder that hangs from the 3030. Its not a standard hypercube evo length
Added an X flag that is 0.5 taller and 1mm longer to make up for the X carriage getting in the way of the flag a little.

9.17.17
A user commented this was a tight fit for him. You may need an 8mm drill bit to debur the rod holes.

1/22/17 added a 10mm x and 10mm y version that someone modified. havent tested myself but will test when my hollow 10mm x axis rods arrive.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This design was created to help adjust the GRBL setting by precisely measuring the movement of each axis as well as the repeatably of these moves so we could "average" out the GRBL values/ I also highly recommend Clockwise Tools DIGR-0105 Electronic Digital Indicator Gage Gauge Inch/Metric Conversion 0-1 Inch/25.4 mm with Back Lug Auto Off Featured Measuring Tool: (http://amzn.to/2udgHgh) along with the Clockwise Tools DTCR-01 RS232 (USB) Digital Indicator Data Transfer Cable (http://amzn.to/2tJwKSx) to allow the readings to imported to the computer for statistical measurement.

Note 1: this model is not fully parametric as the individual requirement for the X/Y support arms vary to need rather being fixed to the model. I designed this for an 800 watt water cooled spindle (65mm) and tested down to a 400 watt size (52mm and up to 75mm) out side of that the strut size must be manually adjust.

Note 1: The STL which is in the file is the one you see and will fit a 3040 CNC with 800 watt water cooled spindle so no need to use the customizer is this what you have. Also it will likely work on a 3020 and 3060 with same size spindle.

Also, please follow us on Thingiverse and give this a like if this came in handy and for more information on this project, please visit us at http://www.DIY3DTech.com as well as subscribe to our YouTube Channel at http://YouTube.DIY3DTech.com along with a visit to our drone site and YouTube channel at http://video-drone.DIY3DTech.com

If you are looking for one of a kind swag shop for yourself or a Maker Geek friend, visit our swag shop at http://Swag.DIY3DTech.com for unique 3D Printing, Laser Cutting and CNC swag! Too, if you want a behind the scene look at what we are working on be sure to follow us on Instagram (https://www.instagram.com/diy3dtech/)!

description.text:
This is a 200mm wide by 90mm deep shelf designed to hold a Fios modem/router to the wall. I haven't personally tested it just yet (I'm out of filament at the moment)

The screw holes on the mounting portion have a 4mm radius opening falling down to a 2.5mm radius at the bottom with a cambered edge which is 3mm thick. Should be more than sufficient to hold the light weight of a Fios modem. Or truthfully anything small enough to sit on this shelf.

This is version 1.0, as previously stated I haven't tested yet myself, I do have a spool on the way and will be printing this shortly, feel free to test at your own risk.

The shelf itself is 5mm thick, while the triangular support is 10mm across.

UPDATE: Honeycomb shelf added to save material while maintaining structural integrity.

UPDATE: 8-9-2017 Shelf Version 2.0 created, 2 additional support beams have been created, with wider supports to allow for wider screws.

title: Z-stepper motor mount upgrade for Geeetech Prusa i3 acrylic

description.text:
Had a fun build and the printer works great .... except .... my student who was building the printer snapped the prongs off the z-axis motor mount. Not sure how that happened, except the design was fundamentally weak with only 2 axis of support (it's acrylic plate). So we designed a z-axis motor mount with a full 3 axis of support, printed on a different 3d printer, and finished our build with the printer already upgraded!

Uploaded the *.stl for printing, and for redesign the source file from FreeCAD and an export into the STEP interchange format. Enjoy!

author: benmcl

title: Making Copper Chain (Heavily inspired by Pocket83)

description.text:
A while back, pocket83 uploaded a video about making copper chain: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=byM292kKPhw

I have the tools to make the jig he made, however my attempt looked incredibly bad and was barely functional. No guarantee that this part will work unless you come up with a solution to cool it down (cutting the copper with a hacksaw / dremel tool generates a lot of heat) My recommendation to prevent your part from melting would be spilling water on it via a pump, or a gravity fed mechanism. I Have also included blocks which you can attach to the sides so that you don't scar up the bottom of the copper coil once the saw cuts through. Lastly, I have included the Inventor files so that you can make modifications to the length of the jig. (The one provided is 4in long and 1in length and width.)
Moved the small 2mmx10mmx3mm slot towards the center more as it easily breaks off.

title: MP Mini Delta Bottom cover with extended legs and fan mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update: I made a few very minor tweaks based off my print that pushed the design to Rev 2 and updated the post with photos.

My MP Mini Delta is overheating and needs more airflow over the Stepper motor drivers. The stock bottom cover has a hole for a 60mm fan, but no fan is included and I didn't have that size fan.
This is a replacement bottom cover I made for the MP Mini Delta. It has mounting holes for a standard 80mm by 25mm PC case fan that I had on hand. It also has extended legs to give the needed height to allow airflow for the fan. I put two sets of screw holes in the design. One set is counterbored to make sure that short screws that hold the stock cover on can reach and the other set are not which makes the screw hole stronger, but needs a longer screw.

I printed this on my Prusa mk2 and it just fits on that bed. If you cut it up into 3 pieces you should be able to print it on the MP Mini Delta bed, but I haven't tried.

I haven't found an easy way to wire this fan into the main board of the printer so I'm just powering it with a 12v power supply I have on hand, but once I dig a bit more and figure out how to wire it in I'll update this post with instructions. The random extra hole is for the fan wires to get inside.

I designed this in OnShape so anyone can easily modify the design by going to the following link and forking the model. Everything is parametric so it should be easy to change the leg height or fan size if that fits your needs better. Please leave a comment if you make a change or improvement so that everyone can gain from it.
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/47af9fd0edb2f59787c8471a/w/20fb0c96cbc036b9260822cf/e/1cef293fce2ec463c843a33f

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10% - 20%

Notes:

I recommend 4 top layers, 3 bottom layers, 10-20% infill and 4 parameters. Cubic infill gives a good 3 dimensional strength and the 4 parameters help with strength on the legs. I printed in PETG, but PLA or anything else should work great too. Approximate print time with 10% infill is 6hrs on the Prusa MK2. Overhangs for feet are 35 degrees.

author: fruitkillr

description.text: This time it's Led Zeppelin. I included the .SVG files I used to create the .STL files with. As always feel free to use this in anyway you please and if you come up with a great design please take all the credit. Just doing this to pass the time.

I created this design while learning how to use my laser, it's a good simple project that creates 35, 1.2in hex pieces that you can build abstract sculptures with. They make a great desk toy or gift with a custom engraving on the peices. I'll be giving several sets out this Christmas.
This pattern creates about 35 pieces, and the only material you'll need is a 8x8in 1/8th (200x200x2mm) piece of plexiglas. 
This plastic was marked as 1/8th inch, but was only 2mm (between 1/8th and 1/16th) I've been able to find this regularly find at my local home improvement store for $1.50. 
35 pieces is enough to build a 6 inch sphere, or some other large abstract object. If you want to stretch them, 7 chips is a good minimum.
This toy is not intended for young children, the edges are mildly sharp and could possibly be a choked on.
I originally drew this in flash, and am including that as well as a DXF.

The outline is in two portions, the "A Part" which contains the outline, and the "B Part" which contains the logo engraving. Since you'll probably want to put your own logo on, you can use the "B Part" as a template for where to align the logos. Both parts have crop marks on the corners for testing alignment. When you are making these parts, do not move the acrylic between cutting the A part and engraving the B part, some of the hex pieces could fall out of the sheet and it would be hard to align again. I'm sure you'll notice the main part of the design has every hex piece right against each other with no padding, so cutting the right side of one hex is cutting the left side of the adjacent piece. This helps put a lot more pieces on a small sheet, but does not account for the thickness of the cut (cerf) of your laser. If the cut is very thick the notch that holds the pieces together will be too wide and the pieces will not will not hold together. If you cut a sheet and find the pieces don't hold together or are too hard to assemble, you can scale the entire sheet up or down by a small percentage. Once you have the sheet cut you can punch out the pieces and remove all of the 3 pointed stars that the notches create. If you make a set and make any interesting structures, send me the picture or link, I would love to see all your creations. Soon I will also be posting the easy to make box that I give these out in. Tune in next week for that here or on my blog, http://4volt.com/blog/ .

description.text:
UPDATE: im working on a new version of this with some improvements in terms of fit that will incorporate all thoughts from this object, corrected measurements and design-refinement for those of you who can't wait (the cad files are ready just not verified by print) please use Aggresives parts in the meantime
i gave them a shot and they made me realice i realy need to improve my version! -> linke to Aggresives Version http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27945 If you can wait one or two days check back here, ill post the new part refference here These are replacement holders for the X and Y (and Z but in my eyes not necessary) axis of the Orca 0.40 and 0.42 Linear Bearings. After a few weeks with the LM8UU linear bearings i just couldn't stand the rattling (noise) any more.
I had lubed them several times with grease and with oil none brought improvement.
A good tip was to mount them so that always 2 ball lines run on the smooth rood (45Â° X alignment) but i still had rattling. So i first went for the printed LM8UU which really eased my pain (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16813) .
Next logical step were IGUS slide bearings but they have a different outer diameter an length than the LM8UU so the original holders won't fit. These holders should snap tightly to the RJMP 01-08 bearings and won't fall off during mounting (part that annoyed me on the original LM8UU holders). I've been printing with them now for a week and i love them. Happy more silent Printing ;) Update: Here's a video of them in action http://youtu.be/on6PA-QSfIc

I used .2mm layer height with a .35mm nozzle and infill is at 35%. No raft needed. If you want you can print a set of 6 and one time.
!! SET X and Y are scaling to 1.01 !!
If your printing ABS make sure these parts are made out of ABS. Cause they are the first parts on your Orca that will suffer from the higher temperatures.

comments.text: Igus also supply a dry linear bearing that has the same dimensions as the current LM8UU, so it should pop straight in without having to print the thingiverse part. However the catch, it's more expensive.

title: Mini Talon Anti-Vibration Flight Controller Tray (Long version)

description.text:
This thing is an anti-vibration flight controller tray for the Mini Talon. The tray is designed to have the flight controller mounted on the top deck and other components such as a current sensor, receiver, voltage regulator & gps mounted underneath the tray or on the extended section towards the rear.

The tray is simply held in place using 4 zip ties and can be easily removed for modifications. There are openings on the tray to pass servo wires through from the bottom to the top. The tray has been designed to fit an APM or Vector flight controller, other flight controllers will also fit.

Anti-vibration Dampeners x 4 - https://hobbyking.com/en_us/vibration-damping-ball-65g-bag-of-8.html

Zip Tie x 4

1. Attach the top deck to the bottom tray using 4 anti-vibration dampeners.
  2. Install the flight controller and any other components such as current sensors, BECs, RXs.
  3. Insert the tray into the Mini Talon and secure using 4 zip ties.

Rotating Brackets-

Here are 4 Different Rotating Brackets in there Printing Positions-

50-Degree ( Rear-end Bolt)
90-Degree
90- Degree (Rear-end Bolt )
115-Degree

Each Bracket has about 3-Degree Overshoot,,,more if using Low Profile Bolt Heads,

There are Slight Changes to each Bracket to suit different situations and all use 5mm Holes for M5 Bolts- use 25mm or 1-Inch to Join them together and 10mm or 12mm Bolts for connecting to the T-Slot-

There designed to be as Strong as Possible in their current printing Position so don’t Re-Orientate them ( I’ve paired them together so you don’t make that mistake like i did,,, )

Their is a very slight amount of Flex with the Brackets that don't have a Rear End Bolt- this isn't really a problem,,,,,, but worth mentioning,,,, it can be removed by Glue or epoxy

For a Permeant Fix in Rotation Degrees just add Glue to the Rotation Arms Faces and set in the required position, or you can Drill Small hole through both Rotation Faces and bolt together—

It really just depends on what your using them for—You might not need to Glue or Bolt at all

Using locking Teeth in 5-degree increments at this scale was a pain in the ass for the 3d Printer so this was a more viable solution,,,,,

Sketchup File is Included for Mod Work,,,

A binary adding machine created with D. Moews' program - see thing:2425746 - "A Slide Adder". The program is available for download at http://djm.cc/slide-adder-0.03.zip. A feature of the program is that one can choose the base of the number system; here base 2 was used. The machine has six digits and overflows if sums greater that 63 occur. However it might be useful for instruction. An exercise is to add 7, (binary 111), 9 times. If properly done the result will be 111111, (decimal 63).

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

To set the adder to zero tap the top gently on a surface moving the sliders so that the windows all show "0". To add a number work from right to left. If "0" is to be added skip the column. If "1" is to be added look to its left. If a triangular hole is present use a stylus to pull the hole to the bottom stop. If a slot is present use the stylus to push the slot up and then over the curve to the stop.

After addition, right to left, is completed "+" signs may occur in some windows. The "+" signs can be cleared as follows; again move from right to left. Add "0" to the columns containing a "+" sign by moving the slot next to the "0" up and then over the curve to the stop. Repeat the process as necessary. The "+" sign cannot be removed from column 32; overflow has occurred.

description.text:
I own this lavalier microphone, which works pretty good for the most part. I broke the plastic bit that holds the actual microphone to the alligator clip, so I used Tinkercad to make me a new one.

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00HX40Q3C/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Fits real tight. It's in there rock solid, once you get it in. To remove it, you might have to use some nippers to cut it out. There's also a lip that prevents the clip from rotating and unscrewing itself, one of my pet peeves with the original design.

You may prefer to have the plastic bit break first, before the wire does, if that's the case, then likely this part may not be what you want. As I mentioned, it's locked in really well.

title: Anycubic Magnetic Ball Joint Carriages and Effector Accessory Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This Modification is for the Anycubic Linear Plus! It may work with the Linear and the Pulley.

It allows you to change to the 288mm Haydn's Magnetic Arms from Blue Eagle Labs.

This is set up to use your existing effector by printing 3 accessory ball mounts and you will need to print 3 new carriages.

Due to the longer arms 288mm vs 267mm for the original arms and the need to place the effector balls in the same XY location as the existing Traxis Ball locations I lost 20mm of Z height after I moved my End Stops to the highest point I could and switching to shorter end stop adjustment bolts.

On the positive side I have no vibration issues and my level is better than ever before!

I can only assume, based on the build instructions this would work for the Linear and the Pulley versions but I do not have those so I cannot test their function.

I have included a step file for anyone who wants to modify this in their cam system to better fit their machine.

EDIT 08JAN2018: I added a new version of the carriage that eliminates the Ball Angle to simplify the printing and assembly. This also adds a few more millimeters of travel. The down side is that the Haydens Arms get very close to the shank of the ball and although they should clear if you are concerned then print the original. Please be aware that I have not printed this modification yet as I am waiting until I do my next round of upgrades.

Printer:

AnyCubic Delta Linear-Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I used PLA but you should use your best judgment

comments.text:
I measured the length of the ball to ball center and that is what I used. I also measured the rest of the dimensions and it only needed a small smooth rod tweak to get it right on. You will notice that I set the carriage offset to zero as this is for people with round rod linear rails which I do not have so I just used the correct delta smooth rod offset. These numbers are what I am using on my machine so realize that yours will be different:
DELTA_SEGMENTS_PER_SECOND 160
DELTA_DIAGONAL_ROD 288.46 // mm
DELTA_SMOOTH_ROD_OFFSET 163.00 // mm
DELTA_EFFECTOR_OFFSET 42.35 // mm
DELTA_CARRIAGE_OFFSET 0.00 // mm
DELTA_RADIUS (DELTA_SMOOTH_ROD_OFFSET-DELTA_EFFECTOR_OFFSET-DELTA_CARRIAGE_OFFSET)
DELTA_PRINTABLE_RADIUS 116

This is a device for mounting the SN04 sensor for the ender 4. I used a 10-32 bolt and made it into a Tbolt. The 10-32 will provide enough resolution, so that 1/12 turn will give you .003" (.06mm) movement. You can use a double hex nut and put a mark on it for better control of the displacement.

I printed mine slower to get better resolution, the tolerances are tight so you may have to do some sanding. I used a piece of sand paper for the final touch. This will reduce backlash on the part and allow you to have better sliding and no unwanted movement on the sensor.

title: Cube Stereo Hybrid - Speed and Cadence Sensor

description.text:
Got a Cube Stereo Hybrid 120, a Full-Suspension E-Mountainbike.

The distance to the magnet on the spoke is much too large to get the BT smart speed and cadence sensor working with.

My used sensor example: https://tinyurl.com/ycpqkn5g

A similar one:
http://tinyurl.com/y7h7xnsd

Designed a base that is tightened with a zip tie to the frame and has the needed socket to install the sensor on it. So it uses the same magnet that is already in position for the Bosch motor and Bosch Intuvia / Purion display unit.

What you should have is a small flat rubber strip between the printed part and the frame sidewards and on top to keep away any movements (and tight fit of the zip tie). Not too big and not too much, the 02_base.stl has only space for one side with 1mm thickness.

Für mein Cube Stereo Hybrid 120 - ein E-Mountainbike mit Vollfederung - hab ich noch einen Geschwindigkeitssensor mit integriertem Trittfequenzsensor übrig. An der Kettenstrebe lässt sich zwar der Kadenz-Sensor befestigen, aber der Geschwindigkeitssensor sitzt zu weit von der Speiche und dem Magneten weg.

Also hab ich eine Halterung entwickelt, die über den Rahmen gesteckt wird, dort mittels Kabelbinder fixiert ist, und für den Sensor die passende Negativform hat, dass dieser so aufgesetzt werden kann, wie an der beiliegenden Gummihalterung.

Den Sensor (link siehe oben) dort einfach ohne Gummi aufsetzen, die beiden Kabelbinder durchfädeln und festziehen.

Damit die Halterung nicht am Rahmen rutscht und der Kabelbinder an der Unterseite am Rahmen anliegt braucht man noch 2 schmale Streifen klebenden Gummibandes.
Empfehle http://tinyurl.com/y8h8rxnc - kauft ruhig eine ganze Rolle davon, das kann man immer wieder mal gebrauchen und lässt sich auch prima zuschneiden.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

20%

There Designed to be Scale to suit your Project,,,,

The Pictures give you a good idea of what there like- I mainly use these with my Brackets and Plates for Testing Frame Designs and for Filament Annealing Testing

I just Drill a 2mm hole and use self-Tapping Screws – Heat the Screw tip with a Flame to Make a Perfect self-moulding thread the wont lead to stress Fractures in the Plastic-

There are in there Vertical Printing Position which gives an excellent result and surprisingly strong Beam using PLA+ Filament- --- Printing them in a Horizontal Position works well but tend to have a lot more flex and will Bow during printing the printing cycle if there not very firmly stuck to the Main Bed –

A heat gun can be used to get them perfectly Straight (if bowed) and help remove Internal Tension of the filament,,,,

Annealing PLA+ and other Filaments parts is still in R&D Stage but here some good information on the glass transition of Plastics

http://pslc.ws/macrog/tg.htm

-=Mindless=-

title: Philips SHP-9500 Ear Cup Rings Replacement

description.text:
The stock ear pads for the Philips SHP-9500 are nice but a little shallow. The fabric also can get a little dirty over time. Many people decide to peel off the stock pads and replace, but since they are glued on, that is a one-way process. I decided to design up a replacement set of the clips that the ear pads attach to.

With some finesse and patience, I was able to get a set of Brainwavz memory foam pads over the new clips and in place with minimal issues. For a really clean look, you will want to glue the new pads to the clips and then cut away a little excess (leave just a little extra so that it tucks in between the headphone and the clip.

Printer:

MonoPrince Delta

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1mm Layer Height

Notes:

You can print at .05, .1, or .3mm layer height. The main thickness is 1.5mm so you will want to make sure your layer height divides into that for best results.

I used supports but if your printer is dialed in for overhangs, you might be able to get away without.

author: TuzNindzya

title: Receiver Box Model with Antenna Mount and Logo Plate Blank

description.text:
So I design this 3D printed receiver box that I call Receiver box
model with Antenna Mount and logo Plate blank. For the purpose of
replacing a modified receiver box that I purchased years ago before
I knew about 3D printing and before it was made available in my area.
This receiver box has an integrated antenna mount for the purpose of
addressing the issue with receiver boxes with short antennas that are
too short in length so the regular antenna mount on the RC vehicle
itself cannot be used as a result the antenna is left dangling around
in the RC vehicle this 3D printed receiver box is designed to address
that issue and it also Does a piece of square plastic for the purpose
of adding a logo on it in the photos it shows my YouTube logo but the
one that you will receive will be blank so you can add your own designer
logo on it as you please and I also because I want my RC vehicle to
look a lot nicer than my modified receiver box. If you wish to download
this file you will need two screws they need to be about 3x20mm and also
you will need double-sided tape and the photo should give you an idea
how to install it so enjoy this upgrade.

But I need to tell you depending upon your 3D printer you may have to use some
super glue to fill in the gap between the antenna mount itself where the antenna
tube goes in and the antenna tube itself so It can get a good secure fit So keep
that in mind. And you may need to use some sandpaper to get some of the rough
edges out so you may be able to open and close the receiver box without too much
effort so all so keep that in mind as well. And also this receiver box is
not waterproof so keep that in mind as well.

author: luisfjdesigner3d

description.text:
Stackable beds sized for Sylvanian Families(tm) and Calico Critters(tm) dolls.
The OpenSCAD files are parameterized and thus changing the dimensions of the bed is easy.
(Design and execution by my daughters.)

Download the STL files, slice them, and print them. Glue the two sections together with acetone or plastic glue.
If you wish to change the bed's dimensions, then download the OpenSCAD files and edit. The dimensions are parameterized and the files documented. Should be straightforward.

author: BridgeBot

description.text:
At night, the fluorescent lighting in my studio is too harsh. With this in mind, I wanted to create a lamp that would allow me to draw, write, and plan.

From the start, I knew this lamp had to be simple. It would be counterintuitive to make a complex lamp that would distract the user from their work. Through personal research, I found that having your phone in arms reach can be a big distraction. To make users more productive and efficient, I created an area for people to store their device when they have a serious task at hand.

Fusion 360
This along with all my other design projects are designed in Autodesk Fusion 360. It is a free cloud based modeling software that enables you to develop ideas and into physical products. Click the link below to download a free trial of the software. I don’t think you’ll regret it.
http://autode.sk/2sx9WHh

Boxzy
My desktop machine of choice is Boxzy CNC. It is a versatile 3 in 1 tool that gives you a new level of possibility that didn't exist before in a 3d printer or desktop CNC machine.

Get free shipping on your Boxzy machine by using code "lamp" at checkout
http://www.boxzy.com

title: Hodor Door Stop (Game  of Thrones inspired)

description.text:
I came up with this one a while back and have been asked to add it to Thingiverse, so here it is. It's far from perfect but I think it gets the idea across.

I'm not sure of who designed the original files I modified but, thank you for uploading them previously. If you provided the files and would like me to add your link and name, please contact me. The various files involved were the Hodor head, a second head, a pair of hands, the body, a small gaming door, and the axe. The wedge was put together by me on Tinkercad. The files went through various iterations finally coming to this point.

The parts included are:
The body with no arms, I found that the hands print out better on the door.
The door with arms attached, the lower rear section of the door has a flat spot that
corresponds with the wedge.
The axe which fits in a small notch at the top of the door above Hodor's right shoulder.
And lastly the wedge with Hodor's name and "Hold the Door' on the side.

The parts were printed on a Prusa i3 MK2 with a 0.06 layer height and 50% or higher infill. The original print was in Colorfabb Copperfill PLA.

I have no affiliation with any companies involved and this was a fan request. I also was inspired by the final design by other Hodor Door stops, this is my variation from both the show and other designers. If parts of this project are too similar in design to an original object I take no further responsibility after posting this file it is free to use and modify as you like.

title: Plane Blade and Chisel Sharpening Sled

description.text:
This is a rolling sharpening sled for plane blades, chisels, anything with flat faces and a pointy end.

Print 2 copies of this part, one for each side. Orient with hex shaped insets facing up.

Requires the following hardware to assemble:

(2) #8-32 x 3" Screws
(2) #8 nuts
(2) 5/16-18 x 1" Bolts
(2) 5/16-18 Lock nuts
(2) Standard skateboard bearings (608)

Already having the bearings on hand, this cost $2.78 in hardware from Home Depot to assemble, and works like a champ. I'm using it with wet/dry sandpaper taped to a 12x12 piece of granite tile, but any truly flat surface will do.

Photos are shown with nuts to the inside, assemble in reverse for narrower blades, like chisels. Tolerances are tight, some slight drilling may be necessary on the screw head side for easier adjustments.

description.text:

remixed_from.title: Root 3 CNC multitool router 3D printed parts

description.text:
This is a housing for a typical Emergency Stop button for the Root 3 CNC project. It will bolt onto the existing pedestals on either the right or left sides.

It was printed in PLA with no supports. I used a paint pen to highlight the raised letters.

8/5/17 - I updated the front panel to tighten up the nut traps for a more snug fit. The Autodesk 123D source is also updated and provided. If the wording "STOP" is not appropriate for your nationality, it should be a simple matter to change.

11/20/17 - In the Thingiverse rendering there is an ugly hole in the face of the box which appears to be a manifold issue from the lettering. The model printed fine for me as well as for others, but regardless it looks like there might be an issue. I have created an alternate version with the lettering offset a bit from the face in the hopes that this will help if anyone has difficulty printing the first one.

description.text:
just a simple port of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2279915 for the 5 inch arms

In the _ledwire_holefix.stl files I subtracted a little bit of plastic to help get the top wire off the back of the esc, using the original LED mounting location.

I found that I could fit 5 pixel strips of 2020 sized led's (https://www.adafruit.com/product/2970) kinda between the motor mounts, you might want to put even more!

i recommend ZX5_version5_2.stl

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.20mm layer height

Infill:

concentric

Notes:

clear PETG is what I'm using.

I also added geometry to help print holes in mid air so you can print it upside down for less support material. Right now they are .25mm thick, but you could change that in the scad file.

You'll have to knock the intentional layer out of the holes, but they should be stronger because of it.

Also you might consider a brim to help keep the print flat.

OpenSCAD stl manipuilation

It is notoriously dificult to edit features on an STL file because well, there are no features... it's just a mesh!

I use code like this to convert this part into a shorter version of its self:

union(){// union 0

..difference(){ //difference 1 part a - part b
....union(){ //union 1
......//part a
......import stl file;
....}//end of union 1
......//part b
......cube to mask off half of part;
..}//end of difference 1

..difference() { //difference 2 a - b
....union() { //union 2
......//part a
......translate(move it to take up the slack between 6 inch and 5 inch version)import stl;
....}//end of union 2
......//part b
......cubes and cylinders to mask off other half of the original stl;
..}//end of difference 2

}//end of union to keep it all together /just in case/

description.text:
The primary feature of the unit is very simple: it monitors an internet connection and power-cycles the connected devices if the internet connection goes down. This simple feature alone can be very useful if your mobile broadband or cable/DSL connection drops, and all you need to do is reset the router to re-gain connectivity - this will automatically reset the router for you, without anyone having to visit the location and manually cycle power. While the unit's main feature is very simple and may be the only feature most customers will use, the unit also includes some more advanced features:

Web Interface: Allows you to monitor status, view logs, and change advanced settings & configurations via web browser
Power Scheduling: Up to 20 schedules may be set to turn power on/off to specific ports at specified times
Logs: To keep track of when the unit had to reset power, etc
Dynamic DNS Support & Remote Admin: Allows customers to log in via the web to access controls, view logs, and remotely turn on/off power to specific ports or reset power
GTalk Messenger Support: Sends you notifications and allows you to issue commands to check the status, as well as turn on/off power or power-cycle certain ports via GTalk
Advanced Network Configuration: Allows you to set up to obtain a static IP address and use different DNS servers and change HTTP web admin interface port
Save/Restore Configuration: Allows you to save and easily restore your configuration. Good for customers who are purchasing multiple units, as they can create a custom configuration file and apply it to all of their units instead of manually configuring each unit
If you are interested in the more advanced features of the IP Switch, check out our 3Gstore IP Switch Advanced Features Review!

Basic Specs:

Dimensions: 5" x 5" x 2"
1 ethernet port
2 controllable power outlets
Tech Specs:

Socket Type 2x North American (Type B, NEMA 5-15R)
Electrical Rating Input: 125~250V~50/60Hz
Output: 10A (for 2 sockets) & DC5V, 500mA (for USB port)
The 10A output to the outlets is independent of the network card’s usage. The network card itself uses about 5W (including the LEDs).
Fuse Type 10A Thermal Fuse
Available Outlets 2x fixed
Internet Controllable socket 2x fixed
Power ON / OFF switch Individual outlet power ON / OFF LED button (Press & hold 2 seconds)
Power Indicator Orange LED
Reset to Factory Defaults Reset button located to the right of the Ethernet port
Internet Indicator Green LED
Web Server CPU 32-Bit RISC CPU
Supported Browsers IE and Java
Supported Network Protocols HTTP, TCP/IP, UDP, SMTP, Dynamic DNS, DNS Client, SNTP, BOOTP, DHCP, FTP.
Network Access 10/100 Base-T , RJ45 (Cat.5)
Firmware Upgrades/Reloads can be done via the GUI or the Utility program (available for Windows and Mac)
Operating Environment 0°C ~ 60°C at 10% ~ 90% relative humidity. For indoor use only.
Certifications CE, FCC (tested to be compliant with FCC 47 CFR Part 2 and Part 15 Class B equipment regulations)
LED Functions
Internet controllable outlets ON Orange LED button ON
Outlet 1 ON, Outlet 2 OFF Outlet 1 LED ON, Outlet 2 LED OFF
Outlet 1 OFF, Outlet 2, ON Outlet 1 LED OFF, Outlet 2 LED ON
System in Protect Mode (UIS On/Off button pressed) Blue LED ON
No Internet Connection Blue LED OFF
Internet is Online Blue LED Blinking
Jet Set Willy in all of his three movement states

title: Glove dryer with 80mm fan (diving, cycling, whatever)

description.text:
I liked the glove insert of the original but we don't have a glove dryer as such. I therefore created a new base to take an 80mm PC fan so we can pump warm air through from our Aga. This takes the drying time for my wife's scuba gloves from "still wet after a week" to "dry in 24 hours".

It should work just as well without the Aga but a warm radiator would help. The fan can be run from a cheap 12V "wall wart" as used for CCTV or an equally cheap USB to 12V module driven from a USB battery bank. Both are widely available from the usual online retailers.

It's held together with 4x M4x30mm and 4xM4x13mm but slightly longer or shorter will be OK. Long bolts go down through the top and short ones up through the stand. Nuts are fitted on the inner faces of the fan using pliers to hold them.

Note that I had a couple of goes at the legs and some pictures show the original thin ones but the stl is for a nice meaty version.

OpenSCAD provided and there's a link in there to the fillet library that's required.

Note the glove inserts can go on two different ways, one with vent open and one with it closed, so you can dry 1 to 4 gloves without losing hot air.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Use supports on the top. I use Cura zigzag with an interface layer and as the overhangs don't need to be neat, minimal support material is fine. I just ripped mine out with pliers and neatened up with a screwdriver!

Just bolt it together onto the fan but do check which way the fan blows first!

Note the inserts can be fitted upside down to block off the holes if only drying two gloves.

author: R3dfox_Studio

print_settings.Notes:: PLA

description.text:
MiSTer - Case v1.0

This is a case for the DE10 Nano board. The case was made for the MiSTer FPGA project.

The case prints well in PLA. Supports are advised for the SD-Card slot section only (extra STL is provided). For the logo make sure you adjust your printer settings to extra fine. Logo can be glued on later should you print it in a different color. Alternatively use
MISTer_v1_Plate_Net_Logo.stl the plate with the logo already attached.

Added new files for the MiSTer logo and front plate with logo for those who want the correct spelling with lower case "i" (all files ending with ilogo).

Update

I added a new top shell for the case integrating a spot for a 40x40x10 fan right above the FPGA chip. It helps with cooling and leaves enough room to place a decent heightened heatsink (with max. of 10.2mm height) on top of the FPGA. There are actually two files.

  • MISTer v1 Top Shell Fan.stl is the one I used - I broke of two of the clamps as it is really snug but otherwise it is a perfect fit!
  • MISTer v1 Top Shell Fan_L.stl is another version with 0.2 mm longer clamps. I made if somebody need some extra space ;-P - Longer clamps would affect the heatsink option.

More info on the case: http://www.atari-forum.com/viewtopic.php?f=101&t=32067

More info on the MiSTer project can be found under these links:

https://github.com/MiSTer-devel/Main_MiSTer/wiki

http://www.atari-forum.com/viewtopic.php?f=101&t=31825

Resolution:

0,18

Infill:

20%

Notes:

PLA

description.text:
Los dos primeros vídeos que vemos muestran un ejemplo del robot DYOR funcionando mediante el control remoto de la interfaz de App Inventor 2, manejado por Bluetooth.
El vídeo que le sigue presenta al robot DYOR funcionando de forma autómata, de manera que cuando no existen obstáculos se mueve libremente con un corazón en la pantalla LED y tocando una melodía de Beethoven. Cuando el sensor de ultrasonidos localiza un obstáculo a una determinada distancia las ruedas giran de una manera aleatoria un cierto tiempo, y se ve en la matriz de LED una cara de enfado.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Fg8mw1tOKls
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WSuC0Ir8opQ
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_rONUxwkwes

Para más información: Curso MOOC EdX: https://www.edx.org/course/disena-fabrica-y-programa-tu-propio-upvalenciax-dyor101x Portal de formación robot DYOR: http://dyor.roboticafacil.es Blog robótica de la UPV: http://robotica.webs.upv.es Twitter (@roboticaUPV): https://twitter.com/roboticaUPV Facebook (robótica UPV): https://www.facebook.com/roboticaUPV

description.text: A simple way to move your keyboard below your desk. All you need is a board, cut to a rectangular shape that will give you the space you want. These parts should work for any size board because all they do is hold if from the edges. There are many different versions of the part, to make sure there is a option for you depending on the thickness of material you have available to you. The file names of the parts include a gap measurement that indicates the maximum thickness board it can hold. Ideally the gap in the part would be 1 or 2mm larger than you material thickness. Make sure you either put stops on the back of your tray to prevent being able to pull it out, or cut your board large enough that you cannot pull it out of all four mounts while you are sitting down at your desk. These parts are designed to use m3 screws to mount to the bottom of a desk. I have drilled 2.5mm holes into particle board without any tapping, and the eight m3x12 are holding very well. Print with at least three outer layers, that increases the strength the best, compared to increased infill.

print_settings.Notes:: if you have layer cooling fan then there will be no problem , this is designed in tight tolrance so the barrings will not wobble, so make sure you have calibrated your printer for that.

description.text:
I have designed this for Flsun cube, it can be used with stock filament holder ( it is upgrade for that) i have used 2 6202 barrings, but smaller barrings can be used too,

One thing that i have noticed is that on stock filament holder , the filament roll if it is haver then 250g will stuck and the extruder motor will have to work hard to pull the filament, but by adding this design we have installed 2 barrings and they really help a lot, you can even see the filament roll back to the RIM when extruder motor retracts the filament during printing. and this design can be used with any width of Filament roll. i will be adding more revisions to this soon.

Flsun Cube

Notes:

if you have layer cooling fan then there will be no problem , this is designed in tight tolrance so the barrings will not wobble, so make sure you have calibrated your printer for that.
Video Beschreibung =>https://youtu.be/4tKrO_gCqQA

Day's 9 and 10 of my 30 days of creativity ( #30DoC ) involved my Kids, they are always such a massive source of ideas and creative opportunity. We have been doing numbers and basic maths recently with them, using the normal flash cards and coins. They are still not visualising numbers all that well so I decided to try and design a basic set of counters that could form games and number play before bedtime.

The main 100 grid is 150mm x 150mm so better to print in PLA than ABS, also try out the 'Brim' setting as proposed by Idolcrasher http://bit.ly/KfkAH0 And if you add a layer of a different colour on the last solid print surface the numbers will be more prominent. More details on my Blog Here - www.richrap.blogspot.com
